# Methodological perspectives - Considering heterogeneity and spatial scale in a complex feedback interactive system

- The first feature standing out from the description of small-scale grazing systems in the NBR is the high level of both *inherent* and *induced* heterogeneity [@fynnManagingBrowsingGrazing2019].

Finally, paper III was our modest attempt to disentangle the effects of environment- and livestock-driven variation on plant and beetle assemblages across scales, which, unlike in other papers, were characterised by selected sets of measured variables. Even if we could only take an exploratory approach due to the limited scope and replication level of our study, this latter paper addressed the most explicitly the complexity of assessing grazing management effect within a highly heterogeneous system.


## The context

- The absence of control can be debated whether our results 

- gradient of intensity -> usually intermediate disturbance the most beneficial for biodiversity
- though we saw variables respond differently 
- studies on grazing, particularly in small-scale or low-intensive farming systems, very often conservation-focused -> diversity/richness, rare species. Less on community or production focused

- grazing mitigating ecosystem functionality between aboveground and belowground compartments see @bardgettHerbivoremediatedLinkagesAboveground2003

### Literature

- grazing and spatial heterogeneity [@adlerEffectGrazingSpatial2001]
- usually positive heterogeneity-diversity relationships [@lundholmPlantSpeciesDiversity2009]
- sward diversity in experiment increases herbage quality [@jerrentrupDiverseSwardsMixedgrazing2020]
- Annual herbage accumulation not affected by species richness [@seitherSwardCompositionGrazer2012]
-	Species richness and phylogenetic diversity negatively associated in dry calcareous grasslands [@reitaluDeterminantsFinescalePlant2014]

- @tonnGrazingInducedPatchiness2019 heterogeneity (patchiness) driven by low-intensity grazing more important in preserving plant species diversity than intensity itself
- grazing by native grazers enhances plant species richness & heterogeneity of plant community on the long-term [@bakkerDoesResourceAvailability2003]
- overall positive effect of grazing (against no grazing) on plant species richness, but more important at high-productivity [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014]
- grazing reduced cover of dominant species, particularly in high-productivity sites [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014]
- decrease species richness with native ungulate exclusion [@andersonRainfallSoilsModify2007]
- higher water-holding capacity, soil nutrients and organic matter content in cattle-grazed savanna compared to abandoned [@augustineFeedbacksSoilNutrients2003]

- landscape intensification did not obviously affected multidiversity (small mammals, birds, insects & plants) [@burelComparativeBiodiversityGradient1998]

## What we did

- Different response variables -> diversity (PI, PII), community (PI, PIII), functional types (PI, PII, PIII)
- Different habitats -> outfields (PI, PIV), infields (PII, PIII)
- adaptation to environment -> gradient of intensity & active modification of the habitat -> range of possible managements (PIII) from the more passive (PIII) to the more active (PI)


## What we found

- weak but significant synergy between plant species richness & nectar value, and between nectar & forage values in infields (PII)
- hints of grazing effects on infields, but yet to show the exact mechanism
  - no direct correlation with plant communities but potential influence through fine-scale environment (PIII)
  - effect of animal partially supported with different vascular plant composition under cows (PII)
  -> take-home - there is probably something but maybe not correct variables (PIII) or enough replicates (PII, PIII)


### Literature

Methodology x categorisation
- landscape influence on plant, birds & arthropod richness depends on the features, metrics & resolution of the classification [@baileyInfluenceThematicResolution2007]

Diversity x productivity
- sward diversity in experiment increases herbage quality [@jerrentrupDiverseSwardsMixedgrazing2020]
- higher nutritive value of herbage in more diverse swards in experiment [@seitherSwardCompositionGrazer2012] 
- different nutrient uptake according to functional group [@chanetonNitrogenPhosphorusCycling1996]: forb shoots with high nutrient content under grazing while graminoid shoots with 3-5 times lower nutrient content under grazing
- decline orgranic matter digestibility & crude protein over season in diverse-oriented system while stable in production-oriented system in mountain meadows [@farruggiaAnimalPerformancesPasture2014]
- response of species richness to herbivory primarily affected by change in species dominance independently of productivity [@koernerChangeDominanceDetermines2018]
- neutral to positive effect of herbivory on species richness even at low productivity, & positive effect increase with productivity [@koernerChangeDominanceDetermines2018]

Soil
- fine-scale effect depends on functional types [@austrheimPlantDiversityPatterns2002] -> e.g. vascular and cryptogams were inversely correlated to soil nutrients and LOI -> negative for former, positive for latter
- light availability & heterogeneity may be bigger drivers than N concentration [@bakkerDoesResourceAvailability2003]
- N fertilisation affect plant species composition [@klimekPlantSpeciesRichness2007]

pH
- mites & to lesser extent collembola most abundant in acidic soils with low nitrate concentration [@birkhoferGeneralRelationshipsAbiotic2012]
- Norway as the country with lowest average soil pH in agricultural & grazing lands due to predominance acid crystalline rocks & absence carbonate rocks + cold climate [@fabianGEMASSpatialDistribution2014]
- low pH decreases P mineralisation rate -> lower P availability for plants [@frankUngulateTopographicControl2008]


## What has not been considered

- fine-scale heterogeneity with its own temporal and spatial dynamic
- in-field patchiness of vegetation structure with different grazing capacities created by cattle grazing [@gilhausCattleForagingHabits2014]
- spatial heterogeneity from the bite to the landscape scale created by grazer at both individual and group levels [@parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003]
- e.g. seasonal variability of soil moisture & inorganic N [@ryelTemporalDynamicsSoil1996]

- temporal dynamic not really taken in account, especially to consider functionality of ecosystems -> e.g. only one-week sampling for beetles (PIII), one-day sampling for site productivity (PIV), agro-services calculated from databases (PII)
- the diversity of practices (and land use history, which can be very influential), is what make ecological studies difficult -> contrary to more normative/regulated systems, there is no general rules for fertiliser use for example. Each farmer will do what he thinks is best without relying on particular guidelines
- the difficulty of characterising functionality
- Feedback - very difficult to take in account, but nevertheless omnipresent are the feedback between grazer/field/plants, farmer/grazer/field and plant/plant/community [@brownImportanceScaleEvaluating1989]
- plant-plant & soil-plant interactions - complex organism-environment feedback hard to identify in ecological surveys but yet essential to understand ecosystem dynamics [@reynoldsSoilHeterogeneityPlant1997]

- the pattern/behaviour of grazers -> we looked at effect of environment on temporally fixed variables & on plants, but we did not look at the grazing behaviour under different conditions [@brownImportanceScaleEvaluating1989]

- different types of measurements -> we mostly considered taxonomic responses, and the only functional response (PII) was calculated from species & databases. Though grazing has much impact on plant phenology, morphology & physiology [@brownImportanceScaleEvaluating1989]

- the overall & indirect effects of farmland practices (not just direct grazing effect), by using for example life cycle approach, especially when perspectives are socio-ecological [@kokEuropeanBiodiversityAssessments2020]

### Literature

Scale
- primacy ecological processes into driving plant trait assembly varies across spatial scales: habitat filtering prominent at plot scale (2 x 2 m) but shift to limiting similarity at finer scale (20 x 20 cmm) independently of species richness and elevation gradient [@scherrerDisentanglingProcessesDriving2019]
- land use & edaphic variables with considerably more explanatory power of plant species community variation at coarse grain (50 x 50 m) compared with fine grain (1 x 1 m) [@raatikainenImpactsLocalRegional2007]
- discontinuity framework [@nashDiscontinuitiesCrossScale2014]
- common issue in multi-scaled studies: arbitrary choice of scale [@dixonhamilCrossscaleContradictionsEcological2016; @nashDiscontinuitiesCrossScale2014]

Historical imprint
- semi-natural grassland species richness & density more affected by 100y landscape connectivity than present one [@lindborgHistoricalLandscapeConnectivity2004]
- we did not take in account land use history @perringGlobalEnvironmentalChange2016 or past landscape connectivity
- past land use can be more important than current land use at explaining variation in functional diversity of mutualists & herbivores as well as multi-taxa mobility traits - field age particularly increase multitrait diversity for all taxa & for herbivores [@leprovostLanduseHistoryImpacts2020]

Forage quality
- seasonal variations also impacts nutrient concentration within plant biomass [@kleinebeckerEffectsGrazingSeasonal2011]
- year-round grazing can lower biomass nutrient concentration and thus fodder quality for livestock [@rupprechtEffectsYearroundGrazing2016]
- forage quality of 6 common forage species affected by sward diversity & livestock type [@cuchillohilarioForageSelectivityCattle2018]

Grazer driven heterogeneity
- different utilisation of forage resources according to livestock type & density of animals [@grantControlledGrazingStudies1996]
- importance of both individual determinism & social interactions within flocks for foraging strategies [@parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003]

- multidiversity and multifunctionality highly correlated with each other, but correlation increase as number of functions & trophic levels do [@wangDiversifyingLivestockPromotes2019] -> but in the case of exhaustive inventory, which is not the norm
- warning towards "specialist-conservationist" perspective, with intensive research for exhaustive inventory -> may be interesting for national-wide biodiversity (e.g. rare species), but to date no "best correlating arthropod group in comparison with overall biodiversity in agricultural field/area" [@duelliBiodiversityEvaluationAgricultural1997]
- belowground soil bacteria richness with the strongest positive effect on most functions [@wangDiversifyingLivestockPromotes2019]
- similar trends plant species diversity with functional trait diversity under different grazing animals [@tothLivestockTypeMore2018]

- Many studies only rely on species richness as a proxy for diversity [@lundholmPlantSpeciesDiversity2009] despite its limitation

- effect of grazing & interaction with other disturbances on diversity will depend on the grain of observation & the level of dominance [@chanetonDisturbanceEffectsPlant1991]


# The take-home from the thesis - From the summary concept

## What has not be taken in account enough

- Scale & representativity - we considered mechanisms acting at very different scales, from nutrient cycling in the soil to big climatic gradients, with a single observational scale (field-level) and low number of replicates
- Feedback - very difficult to take in account, but nevertheless omnipresent are the feedback between grazer/field/plants and farmer/grazer/field [@brownImportanceScaleEvaluating1989]

## Perspectives for the Biosphere Reserve

### Reconciliation human and nature

- A lot of land sharing research is focused on the Southern hemisphere, less in the North (e.g. @ranganathanSustainingBiodiversityAncient2008; @steffan-dewenterTradeoffsIncomeBiodiversity2007)
- smallholders emphasize the positive effects of small-scale farming on local communities, economy & cultural landscape -> different perspectives between the full-time "historical" farmer (National farmer organisation) and the part-time who includes broader perspectives (National smallholder association) [@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006]
- Sustainable production systems -> "diverse, synergistic and tailored to their particular social-ecological contexts" [@prettySustainableIntensificationAgricultural2014]
 

### Perspectives for farmers

- addressing the environmental & spatio-temporal variability not only pertinent for ecological perspectives in increasing understanding of agricultural systems, but also for farmers as it impacts the **functional resource heterogeneity**, which represent the *probability of meeting the specific nutritional needs of a grazing or browsing ungulate over time* [@fynnManagingBrowsingGrazing2019]
- not only "alternative" systems aiming for a more sustainable agriculture are hard to classify due to the extensibility and malleability for farmer's own interpretation, but there is also a lack of knowledge regarding the extent of use of non-certified practices which make it even more difficult to assess their impact on biodiversity and system functioning [@milderAssessmentMultifunctionalityAgroecological2012]

- not yet enough research on grazing systems ? At the end of the day, the end goal is to provide managers/farmers with concrete recommendations to ensure productivity, resilience and ecological preservation. The complexity of environmental variation coupled with management practices is already a lot, but coupled with farmer's commitment and freedom is even more challenging [@briskeRotationalGrazingRangelands2008]

- mixed grazing (sheep with cattle) on improved pasture increased lamb live weight [@fraserAlternativeUplandGrazing2013]


### Perspectives for conservation

- heath habitats, particularly in uplands, very important for carabid diversity conservation [@eyreRelationshipBritishGround2003]
- importance of maintaining ecological gradients even at fine scale to satisfy needs of different taxa -> e.g. soil humidity (+) vascular diversity but (-) wild bees diversity [@dauberLandscapeStructureIndicator2003]
- mosaic-like landscape with well preserved vegetation patches best for biodiversity conservation [@konigGetLargerGrow2019]


### Perspectives in ecological research

- still much research to be done on the effect of grazing & its different parameters on agricultural habitats at different spatial scales [@rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004]

- long-term changes in grazing and burning management at local scale may have broader consequences through how they affect carbon and nitrogen pool [@connellThreeDecadesDivergent2020]

- warning with definitions of communities, with desirable or not species -> not anchored in space & time -> definition @allenConfusionScaledefinedLevels1990
- more focus on arthropods more relevant [@duelliBiodiversityEvaluationAgricultural1997]
- different species richness in beetle families according to land use type [@dauberLocalVsLandscape2005]
- beetle families do not respond equally to environmental factors

- a key asset of Nordhordland Biosphere Reserve agricultural landscape is its mosaic-like heterogeneity. Though we touched on the mosaic effect at the field-scale (ref ØY) and we considered landscape as a variable (ref fjord), we never actually analysed the landscape mosaic [@duelliBiodiversityEvaluationAgricultural1997]. Landscape-scale studies would be complementary to field-scale studies and would allow an interesting approach on farm multifunctionality beyond ecological perspectives only.
- farm level as an interesting scale, as it encompasses socio-ecological processes, multifunctionality -> particularly difficult to isolate individual grazing practices from the rest of management

### Literature

- effectiveness of EU agri-environmental schemes (AES) dependent on landscape complexity [@concepcionEffectsLandscapeComplexity2008]
- "landscape-wide patterns of field size are linked to patterns of land ownership & to land management" [@cloughFieldSizesFuture2020]

Upscaling to farm level
- "We suggest that agricultural landscapes are better understood and modelled when farm structure and functioning is the starting point of the research" @deffontainesAgriculturalSystemsLandscape1995

Landscape research
- importance of habitat connectivity in comparison with management intensity still overlooked, and relationship between the two not straightforward -> the NBR landscape as a "model" mosaic-like agro-ecological landscape would be a good resource to investigate & provide suitable base for modelling [@grashof-bokdamGreenVeiningLandscape2005]

## Transdisciplinary research

@herreroFarmingGeographyNutrient2017

- socio-ecological approaches to investigate synergies between food security and biodiversity conservation @bommarcoExploitingEcosystemServices2018; @fischerLandSparingLand2014; @geertsemaActionableKnowledgeEcological2016; @hanspachTradeoffsSynergiesFood2017
- implementation of sustainable farming practices allowing long-term preservation of resources and ecosystem services requires broadening scale (landscape) @geertsemaActionableKnowledgeEcological2016
- need to dig further into the context-specific effect of management practices on different aspect of farm sustainability to identify trade-offs & determine optimal strategies @germanRelationshipsMultipleAspects2017

- trans-disciplinary approaches integrating livestock production & product valorisation (whole-chain) [@farruggiaAnimalPerformancesPasture2014]

- participatory approach needed to assess and ensure resilience of food system of local communities @menconiRevisitingGlobalFood2022

- @prettySustainableIntensificationAgricultural2014 Perspectives for concrete implementations of sustainable agriculture
  - both scientific & farmer input into technologies & practices which combine crops & animals with appropriate agroecological & agronomic management
  - creation of novel social infrastructure which both results in flows of information & builds trust amongst individuals & agencies
  - improvement of farmer knowledge & capacity through the use of farmer field schools & communication technologies

- @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017 livelihood-centered paradigm for sustainable intensification entails trans-disciplinarity & solution-oriented knowledge generation combining academic & practical knowledge through co-design & co-development of research
- @altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004 Traditional small-scale farming systems all around the world could serve as models for developing new sustainable pathways. Ecologists have a role here to dissect the processes and feedback between farmers and agroecosystems so they can be translated into practical guidelines and policies for sustainable food production and land management.
- @altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004 There is a complementarity between the long-term, empirical
- Farmer knowledge is specialist to the area, but "trans-disciplinary" in the practice. Ecologist knowledge is generalist, theory-based, more comprehensive in terms of underlying processes, but the approach is more narrow, discipline-based
- @foleyGlobalConsequencesLand2005 There is increasing need for both cross-disciplinary and trans-disciplinary research to develop and implement targeted policies for sustainable use of the land which would address short-term human needs, long-term preservation of ecosystem services and resilience of anthropogenic systems.
- @wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018 different visions of the farmer and the ecologists -> they can agree for a common management (e.g. APHM) but for different reasons -> failure of the scheme to bring farmers and scientists on the same perspectives. Also limited traditional ecological knowledge of farmers, which limits their participation/incentives in the making of a management plan, though such management plan can encourage the building of "endogenous knowledge" (**thus key to build endogenous knowledge**). Such schemes should engage actively farmers and be flexible (e.g. hay-cutting time) to encourage experimentation even if it looks like a "bad idea" from first glance
- Increase of complexity of land management arrangements between farmers [@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010] which may challenge coordinate management measures according to common scheme.
- interdisciplinary research -> needs common reference frame (common definition & understanding of concepts) [@dramstadIntegratingLandscapebasedValues2001]

- "agriculture multifunctionality" has been widely used at the macro-scale of policy-making (national, EU), to the point where the meaning has been twisted to accommodate economic view of commoditisation, while exploring the pathways and interactions at the farm-scale would provide more direct and concrete insights by engaging concerned actors and tailoring to their needs and their environment [@wilsonWeakStrongMultifunctionality2008]

# Conclusion

- The aim of this survey was to provide an overview of the diversity offered by the grazing systems of the NBR.
- Thus, we explored different aspects of managements and ecological responses.
- Due to the limited scope of our ecological survey, and its subsequent lack of statistical power, the objective was not to accurately describe specific ecological interactions between livestock and fields, but rather to highlight directions to target for future work within the Biosphere Reserve
- furthermore, beyond the pure ecological meaning/purpose of this thesis, one key aspect of this work was to ignite the communication between farmers, scientists and managers of the BR.
- if this project did not strive for direct collaboration with the farmers, we hope it did build the first step towards a common understanding of the challenges and opportunities towards sustainable land use and food production within the BR.
